awd_titl_txt: Assessing the Structure of Knowledge in Teaching Mathematics
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding how elementary teachers' mathematical knowledge for teaching develops and how it influences instruction and student learning has been a persistent challenge in mathematics education. Very few measures exist that allow researchers to reliably assess the nature of teachers' mathematical knowledge. The purpose of this study is develop measures of mathematical knowledge for teaching in both novice and experienced elementary teachers to more effectively assess teacher knowledge and its relationship to student learning. This study will take advantage of recent psychometric and methodological advances to develop more sophisticated and sensitive measures of teachers' mathematical knowledge for teaching. 

The proposal includes a set of four studies. The first study will examine how mathematical knowledge for teaching differs for novice vs. experienced teachers.   The second study will examine the development of teacher mathematical knowledge for teaching and its relationship to the experience of teaching topics in that area.  The third study will examine how student learning of specific mathematics concepts is related to teacher knowledge of those concepts. The fourth study will involve classroom observations to examine how mathematical knowledge for teaching is related to corresponding aspects of mathematics instruction.   The methodology makes use of diagnostic classification models to characterize teacher knowledge in particular domains of mathematics--fractions and decimals. 

This project is supported by NSF's EHR Core Research (ECR) program. The ECR program emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that generates foundational knowledge in the field. Investments are made in critical areas that are essential, broad and enduring: STEM learning and STEM learning environments, broadening participation in STEM, and STEM workforce development. The program supports the accumulation of robust evidence to inform efforts to understand, build theory to explain, and suggest intervention and innovations to address persistent challenges in STEM interest, education, learning and participation.

por.por_cntn:
The Assessing the Structure of Knowledge for Teaching Mathematics (ASK) project was supported by NSF's EHR Core Research (ECR) program with the goal of generating foundational knowledge in the field with a focus on the knowledge used for teaching mathematics. The non-interchangeable terminology used by different researchers in this area such as mathematical knowledge for teaching, mathematical content knowledge, and mathematical pedagogical content knowledge, among others, reflects the nascent (and contested) theoretical foundations of a new generation of teacher knowledge tests that aim to measure a family of overlapping, but ill-defined constructs. The field faces persistent questions about the boundaries of this knowledge, what it consists of, and how it develops among mathematics teachers during their careers.

We used psychometric methods to achieve the goal. The ASK project team developed a novel survey instrument by systematically varying the teacher knowledge survey items in terms of the mathematical content at stake and the pedagogical context in which the knowledge was applied. By examining associations among item responses from a large sample including preservice and inservice elementary teachers we were able to accumulate robust evidence about the nature of knowledge for teaching mathematics in the first project study. Specifically, we asked preservice and experienced Grade 2, 3, 4 and 5 teachers to complete 5 types of teaching tasks: (1) to solve Grade 4 and 5 aligned mathematics problems, (2) to identify the most common error students make on these problems, (3) to identify other mathematics problems about the same topic and with the same difficulty, (4) to select appropriate pedagogical representations to support students learning how to solve these problems, and (5) to interpret students' work solving these problems. Half the problems involved fractions and the other half involved decimals. We anticipated that teachers would vary in their knowledge for each kind of teaching task, and that those with knowledge of fractions would not necessarily have knowledge of decimals and vice versa. In three subsequent studies, we examined the change in teacher knowledge over one year, the association between teacher knowledge and student achievement, and the association between teacher knowledge and classroom practice.

In the first study, we found that teachers' knowledge of fractions was highly correlated with (and thus indistinguishable from) their knowledge of decimals. We also found strong evidence that solving Grade 4 and Grade 5 mathematics problems (Type 1) was associated with identifying common errors (Type 2) even after taking teachers' knowledge into account. This meant we could not empirically distinguish these types of knowledge among teachers. However, the other three types of knowledge were distinguishable: identifying equivalent problems (Type 3), selecting pedagogical representations (Type 4), and interpreting student work (Type 5).

The remaining three studies contributed evidence that supports a validity argument for using the ASK survey to measure teachers' knowledge for teaching mathematics. The second study examined preservice teachers, early career teachers, and late career teachers over one year. Whereas there were big differences among groups that persisted over the year, knowledge was not significantly different for any group from year to year. For example, preliminary analysis suggest that preservice teachers have lower Type 1/2 knowledge than other groups and experienced Grade 4 and Grade 5 teachers have the highest Type 1/2 knowledge. These differences between groups illuminate the varied ways that experience is associated with different types of teacher knowledge, and that teacher knowledge accrues over a longer time span than one year. In the third study, teacher knowledge and the project measures of student learning did not reveal a statistically significant relationship, but state level achievement testing data showed all four types of teacher knowledge were associated with student learning. The fourth study examined the association between a set of classroom observation rubrics (called M-Scan) focused on standards-based mathematics teaching and teacher knowledge scores. Preliminary analyses suggest the relationships were strongest for the combined Type 1/2 knowledge.

Other project outcomes include:

  • Training 22 graduate student researchers across 5 years of the project in various aspects of instrument design, psychometrics, and validation-focused research.
  • Field testing several novel beliefs instruments that have associations with teacher knowledge.
  • Two dissertations, 4 research journal articles, 10 published conference proceedings, 18 conference presentations with several additional papers and conference proposals in progress.

Teacher knowledge remains an understudied but consequential teacher characteristic with direct implications for teacher preparation and professional development. The ASK project contributed several key findings that shed light on the theoretical foundation for the construct of knowledge for teaching mathematics. The study results imply that teaching tasks play a large role in the structure of teachers' pedagogical knowledge, more so than previously articulated categories of teacher knowledge. These results suggest that using psychometric methods to examine teacher knowledge as in the ASK project is a worthwhile investment.
